articles.headline: Some Women Attain an Enviable Status: 401(k) Millionaire
articles.snippet: More working women with access to 401(k) plans have accumulated $1 million in retirement savings, Fidelity has found. What can we learn from them?
articles.abstract: More working women with access to 401(k) plans have accumulated $1 million in retirement savings, Fidelity has found. What can we learn from them?
articles.lead_paragraph: Accumulating $1 million in retirement savings is symbolic, even if it means different things to different people.

articles.headline: Dueling Appointments Lead to Clash at Consumer Protection Bureau
articles.snippet: President Trump named his budget director as the agency’s acting leader, moving to take control just hours after its departing leader had taken steps to install his own choice for acting chief.
articles.abstract: President Trump named his budget director as the agency’s acting leader, moving to take control just hours after its departing leader had taken steps to install his own choice for acting chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump on Friday named his budget director as the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, moving to take control of the agency hours after its departing leader had taken steps to install his own choice for acting chief.

articles.headline: Scenes From Sears: 2 Locations Tell a Story of Struggle in a Tight Retail Market
articles.snippet: An iconic American company is closing stores and cutting costs as part of a turnaround it hopes will retain loyal customers and attract new ones.
articles.abstract: An iconic American company is closing stores and cutting costs as part of a turnaround it hopes will retain loyal customers and attract new ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILLIPSBURG, N.J. — Every year on Black Friday, Angela Buzatto has come to Sears to buy two new vacuum cleaners, at steep discounts, for her house cleaning business. This year she was going to buy four of them.

articles.headline: Diplomats Sound the Alarm as They Are Pushed Out in Droves
articles.snippet: A State Department exodus marks a new stage in the broken and increasingly contentious relationship between Rex W. Tillerson and much of his work force.
articles.abstract: A State Department exodus marks a new stage in the broken and increasingly contentious relationship between Rex W. Tillerson and much of his work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of all the State Department employees who might have been vulnerable in the staff reductions that Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson has initiated as he reshapes the department, the one person who seemed least likely to be a target was the chief of security, Bill A. Miller.

articles.headline: Inside the Revolution at Etsy
articles.snippet: The marketplace for makers had created a distinctive work culture. Then Wall Street showed up.
articles.abstract: The marketplace for makers had created a distinctive work culture. Then Wall Street showed up.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time Josh Silverman addressed the staff of Etsy as their newly installed chief executive, he tried to connect with a work force known for its diversity, idealism and sincerity.

articles.headline: Culling Voter Rolls: Battling Over Who Even Gets to Go to the Polls
articles.snippet: At a time when gaming election rules has become standard political strategy, the once-mundane task of culling voter rolls takes on new importance.
articles.abstract: At a time when gaming election rules has become standard political strategy, the once-mundane task of culling voter rolls takes on new importance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On its face, the notice sent to 248 county election officials asked only that they do what Congress has ordered: Prune their rolls of voters who have died, moved or lost their eligibility — or face a federal lawsuit.

articles.headline: ‘Please, God, Don’t Let Me Get Stopped’: Around Atlanta, No Sanctuary for Immigrants
articles.snippet: The region has seen the biggest spike in ICE arrests during the Trump administration, and undocumented immigrants in the suburbs are trying to lie low.
articles.abstract: The region has seen the biggest spike in ICE arrests during the Trump administration, and undocumented immigrants in the suburbs are trying to lie low.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAMBLEE, Ga. — Not many notice when the SUVs arrive.

articles.headline: In Egypt, Furious Retaliation but Failing Strategy in Sinai
articles.snippet: One of the most striking aspects of the carnage at a Sinai mosque: How easy it was for militants to carry it out.
articles.abstract: One of the most striking aspects of the carnage at a Sinai mosque: How easy it was for militants to carry it out.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After militants massacred 305 people at a packed mosque on Friday in a stunning assault on a sacred place, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi responded as he knows best.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Jared Kushner’s Vast Duties, and Visibility in White House, Shrink
articles.snippet: Once master of a seemingly limitless portfolio, the president’s son-in-law now focuses on his own projects as speculation mounts about his future.
articles.abstract: Once master of a seemingly limitless portfolio, the president’s son-in-law now focuses on his own projects as speculation mounts about his future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a senior staff meeting early in President Trump’s tenure, Reince Priebus, then the White House chief of staff, posed a simple question to Jared Kushner: What would his newly created Office of American Innovation do?
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Maggie Haberman and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Why Trump Stands by Roy Moore, Even as It Fractures His Party
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell and his allies have been infuriated as President Trump has reacted with indifference to a series of ideas they have floated to try to block Mr. Moore.
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell and his allies have been infuriated as President Trump has reacted with indifference to a series of ideas they have floated to try to block Mr. Moore.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, made the last of his repeated pleas to President Trump to keep his distance from the Senate candidacy of Roy S. Moore, it was too late.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: In Peru’s Deserts, Melting Glaciers Are a Godsend (Until They’re Gone)
articles.snippet: Accelerating glacial melt in the Andes caused by climate change has set off a gold rush downstream, letting the desert bloom. But as the ice vanishes, the vast farms below may do the same.
articles.abstract: Accelerating glacial melt in the Andes caused by climate change has set off a gold rush downstream, letting the desert bloom. But as the ice vanishes, the vast farms below may do the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRU, Peru — The desert blooms now. Blueberries grow to the size of Ping-Pong balls in nothing but sand. Asparagus fields cross dunes, disappearing over the horizon.

articles.headline: Congress Returns to Intense Pressure to End Secrecy Over Sex Harassment
articles.snippet: Representative John Conyers Jr., who paid a secret settlement with taxpayer money, stepped aside from his post as the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee.
articles.abstract: Representative John Conyers Jr., who paid a secret settlement with taxpayer money, stepped aside from his post as the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers are facing mounting pressure to end Capitol Hill’s culture of secrecy over sexual harassment as they return from a holiday break, with members of both parties calling for Congress to overhaul its handling of misconduct claims and to unmask lawmakers who have paid settlements using taxpayer money.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Myanmar General’s Purge of Rohingya Lifts His Popular Support
articles.snippet: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing’s campaign to drive out Muslims, which is widely approved of by Myanmar’s Buddhist majority, may help lead him to the presidency.
articles.abstract: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing’s campaign to drive out Muslims, which is widely approved of by Myanmar’s Buddhist majority, may help lead him to the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The most powerful person in Myanmar now, Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, was little known outside the country’s military circles until the villages started burning.

articles.headline: Amazon, in Hunt for Lower Prices, Recruits Indian Merchants
articles.snippet: Thousands of Indian sellers have shipped bedding, jewelry, kitchenware and clothing to Amazon warehouses to serve bargain-hunting Americans.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Indian sellers have shipped bedding, jewelry, kitchenware and clothing to Amazon warehouses to serve bargain-hunting Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Americans shopping on Amazon.com this holiday season may find that the best deals for popular gifts like leather shoes and luxury bedding are coming from an unexpected source: Indian merchants.

articles.headline: Long Divided, Iran Unites Against Trump and Saudis in a Nationalist Fervor
articles.snippet: Once sneering and cynical about the government, middle-class, reform-minded Iranians are now backing their hard-line leaders amid a surge in patriotism.
articles.abstract: Once sneering and cynical about the government, middle-class, reform-minded Iranians are now backing their hard-line leaders amid a surge in patriotism.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The busiest square in Tehran is dominated by an enormous billboard with a drawing of a young man in the uniform of the Revolutionary Guards Corps, extending his hand to invite Iranians to follow his path. Underneath the image, teenagers line up, flashing victory signs, as they take selfies with the placard in the background.

articles.headline: Time Inc. Sells Itself to Meredith Corp., Backed by Koch Brothers
articles.snippet: Meredith Corporation, the publisher of Family Circle and Better Homes and Gardens, clinches a deal in a cash transaction valued at nearly $3 billion.
articles.abstract: Meredith Corporation, the publisher of Family Circle and Better Homes and Gardens, clinches a deal in a cash transaction valued at nearly $3 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: A long chapter in media history came to an unlikely close on Sunday night with a sale agreement for Time Inc., the publisher of once-prestigious magazine titles including Time, Sports Illustrated and People.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: As Health Care Changes, Insurers, Hospitals and Drugstores Team Up
articles.snippet: Former adversaries see advantages in partnerships as they face the threat of interlopers like Amazon. But will consumers benefit or face a lot less choice?
articles.abstract: Former adversaries see advantages in partnerships as they face the threat of interlopers like Amazon. But will consumers benefit or face a lot less choice?
articles.lead_paragraph: They seem like odd couples: Aetna, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, is in talks to combine with CVS Health, which manages pharmacy benefits. The Cleveland Clinic, a highly regarded health system, joined forces with an insurance start-up, Oscar Health, to offer individuals a health plan in Ohio.

articles.headline: In Tax Debate, Gift to Religious Right Could Be Bargaining Chip
articles.snippet: Conservative Christian leaders are edging toward a once-improbable victory, having quietly worked for years to repeal a ban on political activity by churches.
articles.abstract: Conservative Christian leaders are edging toward a once-improbable victory, having quietly worked for years to repeal a ban on political activity by churches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, a coalition of well-funded groups on the religious right have waged an uphill battle to repeal a 1954 law that bans churches and other nonprofit groups from engaging in political activity.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Meet the Media Mogul of Maine
articles.snippet: Reade Brower owns 18 weeklies and four of the seven daily newspapers in Maine, but media watchers in the state don’t seem troubled by the consolidation.
articles.abstract: Reade Brower owns 18 weeklies and four of the seven daily newspapers in Maine, but media watchers in the state don’t seem troubled by the consolidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCKLAND, Me. — Reade Brower cuts an unassuming figure for a media mogul.

articles.headline: Battle for Control of Consumer Agency Heads to Court
articles.snippet: Leandra English, the deputy director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, filed a lawsuit to block President Trump’s nominee from becoming its acting director.
articles.abstract: Leandra English, the deputy director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, filed a lawsuit to block President Trump’s nominee from becoming its acting director.
articles.lead_paragraph: The battle over who will lead the federal government’s top consumer financial watchdog agency is now headed to court.

articles.headline: How a Radio Shack Robbery Could Spur a New Era in Digital Privacy
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court is set to hear a blockbuster clash on privacy rights in the electronic age. It started with stolen smartphones.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court is set to hear a blockbuster clash on privacy rights in the electronic age. It started with stolen smartphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The case that could transform privacy law in the digital era began with the armed robbery of a Radio Shack store in Detroit, a couple of weeks before Christmas in 2010. In the next three months, eight more stores in Michigan and Ohio were robbed at gunpoint.

articles.headline: Senators Scramble to Advance Tax Bill That Increasingly Rewards Wealthy
articles.snippet: As Republican lawmakers returned to Washington determined to pass their tax overhaul, senators were in talks to resolve concerns that could bedevil the bill’s passage.
articles.abstract: As Republican lawmakers returned to Washington determined to pass their tax overhaul, senators were in talks to resolve concerns that could bedevil the bill’s passage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican tax bill hurtling through Congress is increasingly tilting the United States tax code to benefit wealthy Americans, as party leaders race to shore up wavering lawmakers who are requesting more help for high-earning business owners.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport and Thomas Kaplan
